The applicable standard of review for the Court of Appeals to apply in reviewing the trial court's child support decision is abuse of discretion. The trial court has broad discretion in making child support decisions. Absent a showing of abuse of discretion, such decisions, both under the statutory guideline and independent of the guideline, as in this case, will not be disturbed on appeal.  As this court stated in the case of Johnson versus United States in 1979, they're prepared to countenance imperfections in the trial court's exercise of discretion to enjoy more fully the advantages of making the determination discretionary. Furthermore, the court of appeals is to defer to the trial court's findings of fact, unless they are plainly wrong or without evidence to support them.  There's also the issue in this case of whether the trial court's decision to apportion the fees for the parent coordinator with Mr. Clish paying 75% of those fees and Ms. Sears paying 25% of those fees was appropriate.
